entry.title: Finally understanding kernels and the kernel trick
entry.summary: I've struggled to really understand Support Vector Machines (SVMs) pretty much ever since I was introduced to them. The rudimentary explanation - they are a maximum-margin classifier - makes good enough sense, and for much of data science, that knowledge, coupled with knowing when to apply an SVM to a particular problem, can probably get you by. Still, it doesn't feel great to have so much confusion surrounding something so fundamental to machine learning as SVMs.

.prompt {

/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different

div.output_text {

/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */

<style type="text/css">.highlight .hll { background-color: #ffffcc }
.highlight  { background: #f8f8f8; }
.highlight .c { color: #408080; font-style: italic } /* Comment */
.highlight .err { border: 1px solid #FF0000 } /* Error */
.highlight .k { color: #008000; font-weight: bold } /* Keyword */
.highlight .o { color: #666666 } /* Operator */
.highlight .ch { color: #408080; font-style: italic } /* Comment.Hashbang */
.highlight .cm { color: #408080; font-style: italic } /* Comment.Multiline */
.highlight .cp { color: #BC7A00 } /* Comment.Preproc */
.highlight .cpf { color: #408080; font-style: italic } /* Comment.PreprocFile */
.highlight .c1 { color: #408080; font-style: italic } /* Comment.Single */

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>I've struggled to <em>really</em> understand Support Vector Machines (SVMs) pretty much ever since I was introduced to them. The rudimentary explanation - they are a maximum-margin classifier - makes good enough sense, and for much of data science, that knowledge, coupled with knowing when to apply an SVM to a particular problem, can probably get you by. Still, it doesn't feel great to have so much confusion surrounding something so fundamental to machine learning as SVMs.</p>
<p>The root of the problem with deeply understanding the SVM algorithm is that there are just so many other prerequisite topics that SVMs are built on. Constrained optimization, duality, Lagrange multipliers, min-max theorem, functional analysis, kernels, basis functions, vector spaces, Hilbert spaces, and the representer theorem. Every time I try to make time to tackle this problem, it's just too easy to get overwhelmed by the pieces and just leave it for later. How important can understanding an outdated, rarely used algorithm be anyway?</p>
<p>Well, at the very least the topics underlying SVMs pop up in many other areas and are important to learn. So, now begins my assault on SVMs! (Which will basically not discuss SVMs at all)</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="The-Kernel-Trick">The Kernel Trick<a class="anchor-link" href="#The-Kernel-Trick">¶</a></h2><p>It always bothers me to hear something referred to as a "trick." Many SVM tutorials will explain away the non-linearity of the algorithm as "employing the kernel trick to get infinite dimensions for free," or something similar. Well, that doesn't really compute in my mind; I can't visualize it, and it seems like I'm expected to just gloss over it and accept it as some sort of math magic. No more!</p>
<p>Let's just take a look at a non-linear dataset in two dimensions. We'll generate points from the $\sin$ function with some added noise.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.kernel_ridge</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="n">KernelRidge</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">40</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sin</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
<span class="n">_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We love linear functions. <em>Everyone loves linear functions</em>. But immediately we see a problem - there's a clear pattern in the data, but it's definitely not linear! This shouldn't be that hard. I could easily draw a curve on that picture that fits the data pretty well, so surely there's some sort of machine learning algorithm that could do that as well?</p>
<p>If we just eye-balled a curve, we still wouldn't know what the mathematical formula for that curve would be, and we wouldn't have a principled way to do it again for a different dataset. So, instead we need a way of creating an arbitrarily complex function that fits our data, using a repeatable process.</p>
<p>One way, would be to choose a particular type of a simple function (think: a polynomial, a line, or a Gaussian), and combine several different versions of those functions to make a function that fits our data well.</p>
<p>We can create arbitrarily complex functions from other, simpler functions, which turns out to be quite a useful thing in many different scientific fields. Let's just see some examples.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_basis_funcs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">kernel</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="o">**</span><span class="n">kwargs</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">X</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">[:,</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">newaxis</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">kr</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">KernelRidge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">kernel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">kernel</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">alpha</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.0001</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">kr</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">bases_domain</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">min</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">max</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="mi">200</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">bases</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">center</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">coef</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">zip</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">kr</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dual_coef_</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="n">bases</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">coef</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">kernel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">center</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">y</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">bases_domain</span><span class="p">]))</span>
    <span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">))</span>
    <span class="n">axs</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">base_sum</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">zeros</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">bases_domain</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span>
    <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">func</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">bases</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">axs</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">bases_domain</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">func</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="n">base_sum</span> <span class="o">+=</span> <span class="n">func</span>
    <span class="n">axs</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Basis functions"</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">axs</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">bases_domain</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">base_sum</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"Sum of basis functions"</span><span class="p">)</span>    
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">square_x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">30</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">square_y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">where</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">square_x</span> <span class="o">></span>  <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plot_basis_funcs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">square_x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">square_y</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">kernel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">1.</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">**</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In the plots above, you can see a square wave that is (not-all-that-well) approximated by the sum of several fifth-order polynomial functions. You can also see a sine wave approximated by a series of Gaussian bell curves centered at different points in the domain.</p>
<p>This is a really neat result - you give me a series of points (uh, data), and I can find a function that approximates the data pretty well, using just different copies of a single type of basis function. This is one way we can fit non-linear predictors to a dataset.</p>
<p>Think about an example where we've chosen the basis functions to use as a set of radial basis functions centered at different points.</p>
<p>$$
f_i(\mathbf{x}) = \beta_i \cdot \exp\left({-\frac{\lVert \mathbf{x} - \mathbf{c}_i \rVert^2}{2\sigma^2}}\right)
$$</p>
<p>And the overall function we will form, which approximates the data, is then:</p>
<p>$$
F(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{i=1}^N f_i(\mathbf{x})
$$</p>
<p>So, what exactly needs to be done here, in order for us to fully specify the prediction function $F(\mathbf{x})$? We still need a way to choose:</p>
<ul>
<li>the number of basis functions $N$</li>
<li>the centers of those basis functions $\mathbf{c}_i$</li>
<li>the width of the bell curves $\sigma$</li>
<li>and the coefficients of the basis functions $\beta_i$</li>
</ul>
<p>Fitting the coefficients $\beta_i$ will be the job of the machine learning algorithm itself - and we already know machine learning algorithms are great at finding coefficients that minimize some loss function! Choosing the width of the functions $\sigma$ is a hyper-parameter of the algorithm and is left to the practitioner. Knowing how to choose the number and location of the basis functions is the real insight here, and we're about to learn something really, really cool.</p>
<p>Imagine your data looks like this:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sin_x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sin_y</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We need to choose the locations of some bell curves that will help us approximate this data, where to put them? Putting them far away from the data, is probably not a good idea. How would the lonely bell curve below help us to approximate our data?</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">sin_x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sin_y</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">300</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">kernel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">norm</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">0.1</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">kernel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">])</span>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It wouldn't help at all, since it's practically zero everywhere in the interval where our data points lie. The answer to this question can be found through a mathematical theorem called <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representer_theorem">the representer theorem</a>. The representer theorem basically tells us that, in this case, the best we can possibly do is to put one basis function centered at each of the data points $\mathbf{x}_i$ in our training set.</p>
<p>That's really it. I'll do a more thorough look at the representer theorem in a minute, but for now, if we can believe that it's true, we should rejoice because we have a fully specified way to create arbitrary (non-linear) prediction functions that can be fit to a particular dataset. Now, you can choose your basis function and the hyperparameters, and then simply find coefficients that minimize a loss function, and you'll be left with a prediction function that is optimized for the training set and can be used to make predictions and profit! #winning</p>
<h2 id="A-slightly-more-formal-treatment-of-the-problem">A slightly more formal treatment of the problem<a class="anchor-link" href="#A-slightly-more-formal-treatment-of-the-problem">¶</a></h2><p>Ok so we already did much of the hard work above, now let's just put it all together to make sure the i's are dotted and the t's are crossed and we don't get in trouble from the math gods. Start with a training set:</p>
<p>$$
\{(\mathbf{x}_1, y_1), (\mathbf{x}_2, y_2), \ldots, (\mathbf{x}_N, y_N)\}, \mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^p, y \in \mathbb{R}
$$</p>
<p>We want to choose a basis function to use, like we described above, to build up a prediction function. We need a bit of knowledge about kernel functions to proceed here. Above, we happened to choose a basis function that had a "center" and said that we only need $N$ basis functions centered at each of the $\mathbf{x}_i$ in our data. What if our basis function didn't have a concept of a "center"? Well, in this case we actually restrict the choice of basis functions to be a function induced by another type of function, called a kernel. Kernels are a huge topic, but I'll try to get to just the parts you need for understanding here. A kernel is a function that takes in two arguments, vectors in the feature space of our training data ($\mathbb{R}^p$ in this case), and outputs a real number.</p>
<p>$$
k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y})
$$</p>
<p>The basis functions we use need to be induced by this kernel. What does that mean? Well, we can do something called partially applying the kernel function where we choose one of its arguments and lock it at a certain value. For example, if we had a function which adds two integers $g(a, b) = a + b$, we could partially apply it by choosing $b = 3$ always. That would give us a new function $f(a) = g(a, 3) = a + 3$, which just adds three to the input. Well, in the case of a kernel, we can get a valid choice for the basis function by partially applying it, and locking one of its arguments to a specific value. We can think of that value as its "center." So, the basis function we'd have absolutely has to result from the partial application of a kernel function (a kernel function has many properties required to be a valid kernel, and I won't discuss them here). Our basis function then has to be:</p>
<p>$$
\phi(\mathbf{x}) = k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{c})
$$</p>
<p>where $\mathbf{c}$ is the center of the basis function. Now, the prediction function we are building is of the form:</p>
<p>$$
F(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i \cdot \phi_i(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i \cdot k(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{c}_i)
$$</p>
<p>And given that prediction function, we need to minimize some loss function:</p>
<p>$$
\arg \min_{F} \sum_{i=1}^N \mathcal{l}(F(\mathbf{x}_i), y_i) + \lVert F \rVert^2
$$</p>
<p>The representer theorem tells us that even though the $\phi_i$'s could be centered at literally <em>any</em> $\mathbf{c}_i$ we want, the solution to the optimization problem above will <em>always</em> have the $\phi_i$'s centered at the $\mathbf{x}_i$'s in the training set.</p>
<h2 id="Proof-and-intuition">Proof and intuition<a class="anchor-link" href="#Proof-and-intuition">¶</a></h2><p>My next thought, upon learning the representer theorem was... ok, but show me! Most (all?) proofs of the Representer theorem proceed as follows. Take a prediction function $F(\mathbf{x})$ that is built from basis functions as above, but centered at arbitrary points (i.e. not just points in the training set). Now suppose we have a subspace which is spanned by basis functions centered at the points in our train set:</p>
<p>$$
span\{k(\mathbf{x}_i, \cdot): 1 \leq i \leq N \}
$$</p>
<p>We can then break the prediction function apart into two components: $F = F_{\parallel} + F_{\perp}$ where $F_{\parallel}$ is the component of F in the subspace described above. Now, since we know (by definition) that $\langle F_{\perp}, k(\mathbf{x_i}, \cdot) \rangle = 0$, then we have the following:</p>
<p>$$
F(\mathbf{x}_i) = \langle F, k(\mathbf{x_i}, \cdot) \rangle = \langle F_{\parallel}, k(\mathbf{x_i}, \cdot) \rangle + \langle F_{\perp}, k(\mathbf{x_i}, \cdot) \rangle = \langle F_{\parallel}, k(\mathbf{x_i}, \cdot) \rangle = F_s(\mathbf{x}_i)
$$</p>
<p>That says that, if you evaluate $F$ at a point in the training set then you only need access to the basis functions which are centered at the points in the train set. And guess what? Our loss function only ever evaluates $F$ at points in the training set. So,</p>
<p>$$
\sum_{i=1}^N \mathcal{l}(F(\mathbf{x}_i), y_i) = \sum_{i=1}^N \mathcal{l}(F_{\parallel}(\mathbf{x}_i), y_i)
$$</p>
<p>Seems logical enough, but I still got confused glossing over the whole decomposition part into the parallel and perpendicular parts, so I'm going to go through an example with Gaussian kernels. Consider we have two points in our train set $x = \{ 1, 5\}$, and the prediction function $F(\mathbf{x})$ is:</p>
<p>$$
F(\mathbf{x}) = k(2, \mathbf{x}) + 2 \cdot k(6, \mathbf{x})
$$</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">k</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">norm</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The component in the subspace spanned by the training set is computed as follows:</p>
<p>$$
F_{\parallel} = \sum_{i=1}^N \frac{\langle F, k(\mathbf{x}_i, \cdot) \rangle}{k(\mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{x}_i)} k(\mathbf{x}_i, \cdot)
$$</p>
<p>Note: this is just the same formula used for projecting a vector onto another vector.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">F</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">Fs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">2</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">k</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">Fperp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">F</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">Fs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">F</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'F'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">Fs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Fparallel'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">Fperp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Fperp'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">Fs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">Fs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)],</span> <span class="n">marker</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'o'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">Fperp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">Fperp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)],</span> <span class="n">marker</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'o'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It is not hard to show using the projection formulate above that $F_{\parallel}(\mathbf{x}_i) = F(\mathbf{x}_i)$. So, since $F_{\perp} = F - F_{\parallel}$, then $F_{\perp}(\mathbf{x}_i)$ must equal zero at every single $\mathbf{x}_i$ in the training set. So this says that no matter what function you have, if you only care about its value at the points in your training set, you can always make a function out of basis functions centered at the training data that has the same values as the original function. So, by restricting your prediction functions to have only basis functions centered at the training data, <em>you don't lose any predictive power.</em></p>
<p>Voila! That's about all the intuition I have to offer.</p>
<h2 id="Kernel-ridge-regression">Kernel ridge regression<a class="anchor-link" href="#Kernel-ridge-regression">¶</a></h2><p>The learning algorithm I've used here to demonstrate this concept of basis functions and kernels is called kernel ridge regression, and it's a regression algorithm that just uses partially applied kernels as basis functions. It has the significant drawback that storing the model requires storing all of the data in the train set! SVMs are another kernel based algorithm, but don't have the same drawback since with an SVM, oftentimes <em>most</em> of the coefficients will be zeros (a consequence of a margin-maximizing algorithm). But discussion of SVMs is for a different day.</p>

</div>
